introduction.p: Find the first derivative formula for each of the following functions twice: first by evaluating \lim\limits_{h\to0}\frac{\fe{f}{x+h}-\fe{f}{x}}{h} and then by evaluating \lim\limits_{t\to x}\frac{\fe{f}{t}-\fe{f}{x}}{t-x}.

statement.p: It can be shown that \lim\limits_{h\to0}\frac{\fe{\sin}{h}}{h}=1 and \lim\limits_{h\to0}\frac{\fe{\cos}{h}-1}{h}=0. Use these limits to help you to establish the first derivative formula for \fe{\sin}{x}.

hint.p: Begin with \lim\limits_{h\to0}\frac{\fe{\sin}{x+h}-\fe{\sin}{x}}{h} and use the angle addition formula for \fe{\sin}{x+h}.

introduction.p: Suppose that an object is tossed into the air in such a way that the elevation of the object (measured in ) t seconds after the object was tossed is given by the function \fe{s}{t}=150+60t-16t^2.

statement.p: Find the velocity function for this motion and use it to determine the velocity of the object 4.1 into its motion.
Find the acceleration function for this motion and use that function to determine the acceleration of the object 4.1 into its motion.

introduction.p: Determine the unit on the first derivative function for each of the following functions. Remember, we do not simplify derivative units in any way, shape, or form.

statement.p: \fe{R}{p} is Carl's heart rate (beats per min) when he jogs at a rate of p (measured in ).
\fe{F}{v} is the fuel consumption rate of Hanh's pick-up when she drives it on level ground at a constant speed of v (measured in ).
\fe{v}{t} is the velocity of the space shuttle where t is the amount of time that has passed since liftoff (measured in ).
\fe{h}{t} is the elevation of the space shuttle () where t is the amount of time that has passed since lift-off (measured in ).

introduction.p: Referring to the functions in , write sentences that explain the meaning of each of the following function values.

solution.p: When Carl jogs at a pace of 300 his heart rate is 84\,\frac{\text{beats}}{\text{min}}.

answer.p: When Carl jogs at a pace of 300 his heart rate is 84\,\frac{\text{beats}}{\text{min}}.

solution.p: At the pace of 300, Carl's heart rate changes relative to his pace at a rate of 0.02\,\frac{\sfrac{\text{beats}}{\text{min}}}{\sfrac{\text{ft}}{\text{min}}}. So, if Carl picks up his pace from 300 to 301 we'd expect his heart rate to increase to about 84.02\,\frac{\text{beats}}{\text{min}}. Conversely, if Carl decreases his pace from 300 to 299 we'd expect his heart rate to decrease to about 83.98\,\frac{\text{beats}}{\text{min}}.

answer.p: At the pace of 300, Carl's heart rate changes relative to his pace at a rate of 0.02\,\frac{\sfrac{\text{beats}}{\text{min}}}{\sfrac{\text{ft}}{\text{min}}}.

solution.p: When Hanh drives her pick-up on level ground at a constant speed of 50, the truck burns fuel at the rate of 0.03.

answer.p: When Hanh drives her pick-up on level ground at a constant speed of 50, the truck burns fuel at the rate of 0.03.

solution.p: (On level ground), at the speed of 50, the rate at which Hanh's truck burns fuel changes relative to the speed at a rate of -0.006\,\frac{\sfrac{\text{gal}}{\text{mi}}}{\sfrac{\text{mi}}{\text{hr}}}. So, if Hanh increased her speed from 50 to 51, we'd expect the fuel consumption rate for her truck to decrease to about 0.0294. Conversely, if Hanh decreased her speed from 50 to 49 we'd expect to fuel consumption rate for her truck to increase to about 0.0306.

answer.p: (On level ground), at the speed of 50, the rate at which Hanh's truck burns fuel changes relative to the speed at a rate of -0.006\,\frac{\sfrac{\text{gal}}{\text{mi}}}{\sfrac{\text{mi}}{\text{hr}}}.

solution.p: Twenty seconds after lift-off the space shuttle is cruising at the rate of 266.

answer.p: Twenty seconds after lift-off the space shuttle is cruising at the rate of 266.

solution.p: Twenty seconds after lift-off the velocity of the space shuttle is increasing at the rate 18.9\,\frac{\sfrac{\text{mi}}{\text{hr}}}{\text{s}}. So, we'd expect that 19 seconds into lift-off the velocity was about 247.1 and 21 seconds into lift-off the velocity will be about 284.9.

answer.p: Twenty seconds after lift-off the velocity of the space shuttle is increasing at the rate 18.9\,\frac{\sfrac{\text{mi}}{\text{hr}}}{\text{s}}.

solution.p: Twenty seconds after lift-off the space shuttle is at an elevation of 0.7.

answer.p: Twenty seconds after lift-off the space shuttle is at an elevation of 0.7.

solution.p: Twenty seconds after lift-off the space shuttle's elevation is increasing at a rate of 0.074. So, we'd expect that 19 seconds into lift-off the elevation was about 0.626 and 21 seconds into lift-off the elevation will be about 0.774.

answer.p: Twenty seconds after lift-off the space shuttle's elevation is increasing at a rate of 0.074.

introduction.p: It can be shown that the derivative formula for the function f defined by \fe{f}{x}=\frac{2x^3+2x+1}{3+5x^2} is \fe{\fd{f}}{x}=\frac{10x^4+8x^2-10x+6}{25x^4+30x^2+9}.

statement.p: Determine the equation of the tangent line to f at 1.

solution.p: The point on f when x=1 is \point{1}{\frac{5}{8}}. The value of \fe{\fd{f}}{1} tells us the slope of the tangent line to f through \point{1}{\frac{5}{8}}; this value is \frac{7}{32}. Consequently, the equation of the tangent line to f at 1 is y=\frac{7}{32}\left(x-1\right)+\frac{5}{8}.

statement.p: A graph of f is shown in ; axis scales have deliberately been omitted from the graph.

paragraphs.p: The graph shows that f quickly resembles a line. In a detailed sketch of f we would reflect this apparent linear behavior by adding a skew asymptote. What is the slope of this skew asymptote?

image.description: a plot of a curve; there is an x-axis and a y-axis, but no tick marks for a sense of scale; the curve begins just a little above and to the right from the origin; the curve here has an arrow to the left, indicating that it continues to the left, but that part of it is omitted form the picture; the curve extends to the right with a small positive slope, but that slope gradually increases; the slope appears to reach some value and stay there, giving most of the curve the appearance of being a straight line with a positive slope; the curve exits the graph on its right edge still seeming to have a straight line shape
